Award.AwardTitle: Electrical Engineering Scholars at Suffolk University

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration: This project is supporting three cohorts of academically talented students with demonstrated financial need in attaining baccalaureate degrees in electrical engineering at Suffolk University. Scholar recruitment is being done in partnership with the Boston Public High School system, with additional support from local power industries. Cohort-building and developmental activities for scholars build on best practices from other institutions and include a project-based first-year seminar, enrichment and career-development sessions, course-affiliated study groups, faculty and peer mentoring, and internship opportunities. The intellectual merit of the project lies in a cohesive and focused approach to scholar recruitment, retention and career transitions which leverages strong participation by high schools and industry and the supportive community of electrical-engineering students and faculty at Suffolk. The broader impacts include expanding and diversifying the power-industry workforce, as well as providing a well-assessed model for consideration by similar institutions.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merit

The features of the Electrical Engineering Scholars at Suffolk University program which included the full cost of tuition and books, a pre-matriculation three-night trip to a Maine field station, a freshman seminar, career counseling exercises, study groups, exposure to the electric power industry, and outreach activities resulted in an 87% three-year retention rate for financially disadvantaged, mainly minority students who would typically not consider majoring in engineering. To date, 100% of students who were retained to the second year have either graduated or are targeted to graduate within five years of matriculating as freshmen.

Broader Impact

More electrical engineers, particularly power engineers, have resulted from the program.  To date, 7 of the 8 graduates and 3 of the 5 seniors are employed in the electrical engineering field with 9 working in electric power, an industry which is suffering from a shortage of engineers. Ten of these 13 scholars are from underrepresented groups: one is African American, and nine are Latino American. Through the program's outreach activities, the scholars have interacted with hundreds of Boston high schoolers and middle schoolers, the majority of whom are from underrepresented groups, teaching them about electrical engineering and electric power.

Table 1 illustrates HS GPA, SAT math scores, current or final GPA, and current jobs for graduates for the 15 of the 19 scholars who started as electrical engineering majors[1]. Three Boston Public High Schools (BPHS) were partners in this program, and 7 of the 15 scholars came from these schools; 3 came from other BPHS; 1 came from a Boston community college; and 4 came from Massachusetts public schools near Boston. Ten are Latino American, two are African American, three are Asian American, and all identify as male. The criteria were a minimum 470 SAT math score and 2.7 HS GPA, and we slightly relaxed the criteria for two candidates, one of whom (HS GPA of 2.5) was an existing Suffolk student with a GPA of 3.5 and the other (SAT math score of 460) came from a partner school which later closed for weak student performance. Both of those students succeeded in the program, with the former currently working as an electrical engineer/ manager-in-training for a partner company and the latter working as an electrical engineer also from a partner company. The average SAT math score is 558 and HS GPA is 3.3 for the fifteen scholars. The average current/final GPA is a 3.1.

To better understand how the program's features contribute to a student's success, also provided in Table 1 are the levels of participation in the program's activities which include participation in: a four-day pre-matriculation trip to Maine, remedial math courses when advised, weekly pizza events, study groups, career development exercises, Power Engineering Day, experiments at BPHS, Latino STEM Alliance (LSA) outreach activities to middle schoolers, and IEEE PES events. Figures 1 and 2 show respectively the Current/Final GPA vs HS GPA and SAT math score as well as participation level.

The data suggests that the more engaged the student was in the program and its activities, the higher was the student's likelihood of success. Engagement with other students, along with academic pursuits such as attending study groups and taking remedial math courses, as well as engagement in professional events, compensated for a weaker academic background. The scholarship enables a student to avail himself of these activities, allowing the student to attend college tuition free, mitigating the need for an outside job. This aspect is particularly important for the academically weaker student because it allows him to focus on school without having the burden of work outside of school.

The outside evaluator Davis Research Square Associates concluded its final report  with the following observations:

The  data and interpretations offer a compelling picture of a highly ambitious project reaching its goals of fostering local, academically talented and financially challenged students to study electrical engineering at Suffolk University.  The many program components provided important supports both in helping the students learn more about academics and careers, but also in helping to create a more cohesive group, one that reached across cohorts.  

In conclusion, the Suffolk program can be confidently described as enviably successful, from the recruitment of local Boston public school students through their successful completion of the engineering (or related) studies.  The many program components surely all played a part in the success of the program, but in our judgment, most of the credit must be given to the project leadership whose apparently indefatigable efforts galvanized a responsive faculty in support of the S-STEM Scholars, identified and deployed the necessary resources, and fostered the students into forming a cohesive group whose members could provide one another with moral, academic, and other support. 

 

 


[1] Because Suffolk closed the EE major, the other four scholars are Biology or Computer Science majors
